greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(1) = 0; for n>1, find largest integer k such that the word a(1)a(2)...a(n-1) is of the form xy^k for words x and y (where y has positive length), i.e., k = the maximal number of repeating blocks at the end of the sequence so far; then a(n) = floor(k/2).
comment: When does the first 3 occur? The first 4?
link: F. J. van de Bult, D. C. Gijswijt, J. P. Linderman, N. J. A. Sloane and Allan Wilks, A Slow-Growing Sequence Defined by an Unusual Recurrence, J. Integer Sequences, Vol. 10 (2007), #07.1.2.
F. J. van de Bult, D. C. Gijswijt, J. P. Linderman, N. J. A. Sloane and Allan Wilks, A Slow-Growing Sequence Defined by an Unusual Recurrence [pdf, ps].
Index entries for sequences related to Gijswijt's sequence
xref: A (presumably) even slower-growing sequence than A090822.
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, Mar 14 2004
